inference:
Let $\angle ADE = x$. Since $\triangle AED$ is isosceles, $\angle DAE = \angle ADE = x$.
Since $\angle DEC = 2 \angle ADE$, we have $\angle DEC = 2x$.
In $\triangle AED$, $\angle DAE + \angle ADE + \angle AED = 180^\circ$, so $x+x+\angle AED = 180^\circ$, thus $2x + \angle AED = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AED = 180^\circ - 2x$.
In $\triangle BEC$, $\triangle BEC$ is isosceles, so $\angle CBE = \angle BCE$.
$\angle BEC + \angle CBE + \angle BCE = 180^\circ$.
Let $\angle CBE = \angle BCE = y$.
$\angle BEC = 180^\circ - 2y$.
$\angle AED + \angle BEC = 180^\circ$, so
$180^\circ - 2x + 180^\circ - 2y = 180^\circ$.
$360^\circ - 2x - 2y = 180^\circ$.
$2x + 2y = 180^\circ$, so $x+y = 90^\circ$.
$\angle AED + \angle BEC = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AEB = 360^\circ - (\angle AED + \angle BEC) = 360^\circ - 180^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AEB = \angle AED + \angle DEC + \angle CEB = 180^\circ - 2x + 2x + 180^\circ - 2y = 360^\circ - 2y = 180^\circ$.
We are given $\angle DAE = 70^\circ$, so $x = 70^\circ$.
$x + y = 90^\circ$.
$70^\circ + y = 90^\circ$.
$y = 20^\circ$.
Thus, $\angle CBE = 20^\circ$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{20}$
ground_truth:
Since $\triangle ADE$ is isosceles, then $\angle AED=\angle EAD=70^\circ$.

Since the angles in $\triangle ADE$ add to $180^\circ$, then $\angle ADE = 180^\circ - 2(70^\circ) = 40^\circ$.

Since $\angle DEC=2(\angle ADE)$, then $\angle DEC = 2(40^\circ)=80^\circ$.

Since $AEB$ is a straight line, then $\angle CEB = 180^\circ - 80^\circ - 70^\circ = 30^\circ$.

Since $\triangle EBC$ is isosceles, then $\angle ECB=\angle EBC$.

Thus, in $\triangle EBC$, $30^\circ + 2(\angle EBC)=180^\circ$ or $2(\angle EBC)=150^\circ$ or $\angle EBC=\boxed{75^\circ}$.

Since $\angle DEC = 2 \angle ADE$, we have $\angle DEC = 2x$.
In $\triangle AED$, $\angle DAE + \angle ADE + \angle AED = 180^\circ$, so $x+x+\angle AED = 180^\circ$, thus $2x + \angle AED = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AED = 180^\circ - 2x$.
In $\triangle BEC$, $\triangle BEC$ is isosceles, so $\angle CBE = \angle BCE$.
$\angle BEC + \angle CBE + \angle BCE = 180^\circ$.
Let $\angle CBE = \angle BCE = y$.
$\angle BEC = 180^\circ - 2y$.
$\angle AED + \angle BEC = 180^\circ$, so
$180^\circ - 2x + 180^\circ - 2y = 180^\circ$.
$360^\circ - 2x - 2y = 180^\circ$.
$2x + 2y = 180^\circ$, so $x+y = 90^\circ$.
$\angle AED + \angle BEC = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AEB = 360^\circ - (\angle AED + \angle BEC) = 360^\circ - 180^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$\angle AEB = \angle AED + \angle DEC + \angle CEB = 180^\circ - 2x + 2x + 180^\circ - 2y = 360^\circ - 2y = 180^\circ$.

$x + y = 90^\circ$.

Let $\angle ADE = x$. Since $\triangle AED$ is isosceles, $\angle DAE = \angle ADE = x$.
Given $\angle DEC = 2\angle ADE = 2x$.
In $\triangle AED$, $x + x + \angle AED = 180^\circ \implies \angle AED = 180^\circ - 2x$.

In $\triangle BEC$, $y + y + \angle BEC = 180^\circ \implies \angle BEC = 180^\circ - 2y$.

ground_truth:
Since $\triangle ADE$ is isosceles, then $\angle AED=\angle EAD=70^\circ$.

Since the angles in $\triangle ADE$ add to $180^\circ$, then $\angle ADE = 180^\circ - 2(70^\circ) = 40^\circ$.

Since $\angle DEC=2(\angle ADE)$, then $\angle DEC = 2(40^\circ)=80^\circ$.

Since $AEB$ is a straight line, then $\angle CEB = 180^\circ - 80^\circ - 70^\circ = 30^\circ$.

Since $\triangle EBC$ is isosceles, then $\angle ECB=\angle EBC$.

Thus, in $\triangle EBC$, $30^\circ + 2(\angle EBC)=180^\circ$ or $2(\angle EBC)=150^\circ$ or $\angle EBC=\boxed{75^\circ}$.
